questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following characteristic features would you expect to see in a histopathology 
slide of conjunctiva?

options.a: Amacrine cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
options.b: Goblet cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
options.c: Goblet cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
options.d: Amacrine cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

questions.explanation:
The presence of goblet cells within the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium would help 
identify the conjunctiva. Goblet cells are involved in the secretion of mucin. Amacrine cells are a type of retinal interneuron, and hence would be found in the retina, not the 
conjunctiva.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
questions.explanation:
Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular 
conjunctivitis which is a type of chronic conjunctivitis. Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis where there is inflammation of the 
conjunctiva at the lid margins and the inner and outer canthi of the eyes with red, scaly, 
excoriated, macerated and fissured skin at the canthi. This is because of the proteolytic enzymes 
secreted by the Moraxella species. Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation and 
collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. These patients can also have associated 
blepharitis and papillary and follicular conjunctivitis. Causative organisms are Moraxella lacunata, Moraxella axenfeld and Staphylococcus aureus (Rare 
cause). The source of infection is typically the nasal tract or the nasal discharge of patients with 
angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes 
through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs. Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment 
for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide as it inhibits proteolytic enzymes. The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis. 99 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option B: Haemophilus influenzae causes acute conjunctivitis. Option C: Adenovirus is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis and it most commonly 
causes follicular conjunctivitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Option D: Coxsackie B virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, pericarditis, and 
myocarditis. There are no known mentions of ocular disease caused by the virus. Note: Pathogens that cause bacterial conjunctivitis The below-given table elaborates on the type of conjunctivitis caused by different serotypes of

questions.question:
Question 3: A child presents with irritation and redness of the left eye at a primary health center. There 
are no previous immunization records. Examination showed a greyish-white membrane over 
the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva which bled on peeling. What is the likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
The of a child with irritation and redness of the eye with no previous vaccination records is 
suggestive of a case of membranous conjunctivitis and among the given options, Corynebacterium 
diphtheriae is the most likely etiological agent. Membranous conjunctivitis presents with irritation and redness of the eye and is characterized by 
the formation of a greyish-white membrane that bleeds on peeling. Vaccines are routinely used 
to prevent diphtheria infection and hence, unvaccinated status increases his susceptibility to the 
bacteria. Moreover, the bacteria thrive in crowded populations and poor hygienic surroundings, 
hence a background of low socioeconomic context, such as an orphanage, acts as a risk factor in 
this case. This condition is associated with the formation of fibrinous exudates on the surface and into the 
substance of the conjunctival epithelium. The causes include beta-hemolytic streptococci, 
Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus aegyptius, Corynebacterium diphtheria, and Neisseria 
gonorrhea The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pseudomembranous conjunctivitis. It 
differs from membranous conjunctivitis in that the membrane can be easily peeled off in this 
condition leaving an intact underlying epithelium.

questions.question:
Question 4: A child with pharyngitis, and fever subsequently develops conjunctivitis. Initially, the left eye 
was affected, followed by the right eye's involvement in 2 days. Epiphora, conjunctival 87 
Sold by @itachibot hyperemia, and chemosis are noted. What is its most likely etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
This child with pharyngitis and subsequent involvement of the eyes most likely has 
pharyngoconjunctival fever. This condition is commonly caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, and 
7. Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute and highly infectious illness characterized by fever, 
pharyngitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis, and regional lymphoid hyperplasia with tender, 
enlarged preauricular adenopathy. Within the classical triad, symptoms may vary in severity. It is 
usually bilateral, with one eye typically having onset 1-3 days prior to the second eye. It is a 101 
Sold by @itachibot self-limiting disease and treatment is mainly symptomatic, as follows: • Cold compresses several times per day for 1-2 weeks. • Artificial tears 4-8 times per day for 1-3 weeks. Newcastle conjunctivitis is usually clinically indistinguishable from this condition and is derived 
from contact with diseased fowls. Another conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus serotypes 8, 19 
and 37 is known as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pharyngoconjunctival fever. Significant 
conjunctival hyperemia, petechial subconjunctival hemorrhages, and conjunctival follicles are 
noted.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.a: The condition is commonly associated with a benign course.
options.b: It can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension.
options.c: The blood gets absorbed gradually in 6-8 weeks time without treatment.
options.d: Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.explanation:
The image given above shows a subconjunctival haemorrhage in the eye. In this condition, the 
blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks time without treatment. A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture 
of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension or after 
local trauma. The condition is commonly associated with a benign course but, if the posterior 
limit of the hemorrhage is not seen, one should check for the base of the skull fracture. Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukaemia. The use of 
NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.question:
Question 6: A UNICEF volunteer presented with a bilateral red eye of 2 days duration beginning on a 
return flight from Ghana. The infection spread among all her family members within a day of 
her return. Initial examination revealed lid edema, serous discharge, and severe 
sub-conjunctival hemorrhage. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with bilateral red-eye and a rapid spread of infection to 
family members points towards a likely diagnosis of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Examination 
findings of lid edema, serous discharge, and subconjunctival hemorrhage further consolidate this 102 
Sold by @itachibot diagnosis. Causes: • Enterovirus 70 (most important) • Coxsackievirus 24 • Echovirus 34 • Adenovirus • Pneumococcus • Haemophilus There is no treatment currently available. The infection generally resolves itself within a five to 
seven-day period. The use of steroids can actually cause a corneal microbial superinfection which 
then requires antimicrobial therapy to eliminate. The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

questions.question: Question 7: What is the cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.explanation:
Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornoviruses namely enterovirus 70. Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis also known as "Apollo conjunctivitis" is caused by 
picornoviruses such as enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus A24. Rarely it is also caused by 
adenovirus type 11. It manifests with severe conjunctival congestion, chemosis, subconjunctival hemorrhages, painful 
follicular conjunctivitis, tearing, lid edema and pre-auricular lymphadenopathy. The cornea may 
demonstrate a fine punctate keratopathy. The disease is usually self-limiting, running a course of 
3-7 days. The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. 103 
Sold by @itachibot Enterovirus 71 (Option D) is associated with fatal meningitis, encephalitis, and paralysis. It is also 
implicated in Hand-Foot-Mouth disease(HFMD) and Herpangia which is 
papulo-vesiculo-ulcerative rash in oral cavity.

questions.question:
Question 8: A tribal farmer, presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had 
spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes 
such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed on examination. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised 
whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis 
of pinguecula. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a 
risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains. Pinguecula has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located 
nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that 
adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased 
incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in 
almost all by 80 years of age. Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may 
be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically 
unsatisfactory.

questions.question: Question 9: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.explanation:
The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium. Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a degenerative 
condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue and is never inflammatory. It occurs due to exposure 
to UV-B radiation and the most common site is the nasal. 104 
Sold by @itachibot It is made up of three parts, "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and 
a body. Clinical features: • Astigmatism with the rule - most common finding • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge • Fuchs islets - small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, 
often present at the advancing edge. The differential diagnosis is pseudo pterygium. The treatment for pterygium is usually excision. To prevent a recurrence, mitomycin C or 5 
fluorouracil is used. Other methods: • Auto-grafting- Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is 
the best method. • Bare sclera technique- high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%. • PERFECT surgery- zero rates of recurrence. (PERFECT stands for Pterygium Extended Removal 
Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant) Pterygium

questions.question:
Question 10: The excision of a pinkish, triangular tissue growth at the 1 o’clock position of the eye is being 
performed. The patient had a history of blurry vision and persistent redness in both eyes for a 
month. In order to secure the graft in the scleral bed, which of the following will not be used?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette, with symptoms of blurry vision and persistent redness, along with 
findings of an abnormal triangular mass of thickened conjunctiva, is suggestive of pterygium. 
Cyanoacrylate is not used for pterygium surgery. The various glues used in ophthalmology are as follows: • Cyanoacrylate glue- Mainly used as a corneal patch to seal acute corneal perforations and 
improve visual outcomes, with reduced enucleation rates and need for tectonic keratoplasty • Fibrin glue- It is a biological adhesive, which reduces the total surgical time. It is used in corneal 
and conjunctival surgeries, squint surgeries, cataract (to fix the haptics of intraocular lens [IOL] to 
the tissue in place of sutures in glued IOL), refractive surgeries, trabeculectomy, and even retinal 
surgeries. • Newer tissue adhesives like bio-dendrimers and photo-cross-linkable adhesives- 105 
Sold by @itachibot • Bovine serum albumin-based bioadhesives: used in squint surgery • Riboflavin-based bioadhesive activated on exposure to ultraviolet A: used in post-LASIK ectasia, 
infectious keratopathy, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy • Hyaluronic acid-based photocatalytic glue activated with argon LASER: used in the repair of 
corneal lacerations

questions.question:
Question 11: A man presented with red eyes associated with a sandy, gritty sensation. He was diagnosed 
with conjunctivitis last week, however, his symptoms persisted. He has had multiple sexual 
partners in the past. Examination revealed palpable preauricular nodes and a follicular 90 
Sold by @itachibot reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds. Conjunctival scrapings were 
sent for culture. What is the likely organism involved?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of red eyes, along with the examination findings of palpable 
preauricular nodes and follicular reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds, is 
suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis. It is also known as chlamydial conjunctivitis, caused by 
Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D–K. It is a sexually transmitted disease occurring commonly in 
young adults. The modes of transmission include orogenital activities and hand-to-eye spread of infective genital 
secretions. Hence, it is important to treat all sexual partners simultaneously to prevent 
re-infection and to rule out other venereal diseases, such as gonorrhoea and syphilis. Treatment 
includes a single 1g dose of azithromycin or doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 7 days. The image given below shows the eye of a patient with chlamydial conjunctivitis.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following conditions is closely related to mucus fishing syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Mucus fishing syndrome is closely related to giant papillary conjunctivitis. In Mucus fishing syndrome, patients develop a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual 
removal of mucus. The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as 
giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC). It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; 
in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 106 
Sold by @itachibot The increased risk in contact lens users is because of the build-up of proteinaceous deposits and 
cellular debris on the contact lens surface. It may be also be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed 
sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.

questions.question:
Question 13: A young man presented with watering, redness and photophobia. He had similar complaints 
in the past which improved with self-medicated topical drops. His best-corrected visual acuity 
is 6/36 improving to 6/24. Slit-lamp examination revealed a 3 mm × 2 mm epithelial defect in 
the paracentral part of the cornea that stained positive with fluorescein dyes. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of spring catarrh. Slit-lamp examination finding of shield 
ulcer is typical of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or warm weather conjunctivitis (another name 
of VKC). Shield ulcers are transverse ulcers seen in the upper cornea due to epithelial macroerosions 
in VKC. It is a rare complication of VKC and should always be kept in mind for patients suffering 
from vernal conjunctivitis. Corneal signs in VKC: • Shield ulcers • Vernal plaques • Subepithelial scarring • Pseudo-gerontoxon- resembles arcus senilus; has a cupid's bow outline Treatment of VKC is mainly with allergy avoidance and lid hygiene. Cool compresses, topical 
antihistamines, topical NSAIDs and topical steroids can be used to reduce the intensity of 
symptoms. The image given below shows a shield ulcer in a patient with VKC.

questions.question:
Question 14: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public 
health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as 
the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What 
is the likely diagnosis? 91 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
107 
Sold by @itachibot The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most 
important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. Conjunctival appearance: 1. In trachoma • Sago-grain appearance • A follicular reaction 2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis • Cobblestone appearance • A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva 3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis • White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva 4. Xerophthalmia • Epithelial xerosis • Bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

questions.question:
Question 16: A young girl has been brought in by her grandmother because she has constant pain, 
photosensitivity and discharge from her eyes. From the notes, you see that the child has had 
multiple presentations for prior eye infections. You observe severe scarring on the palpebral 
conjunctiva, as well as trachomatous trichiasis. Which McCallan stage will this be classified 
under?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette of a young child with pain, photosensitivity and discharge, having repeated 
infections, along with findings of scarring and trichiasis is suggestive of trachoma. Cicatrising 
trachoma is stage 3 of trachoma and is characterized by scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva. Cicatricial trachoma is the end result of scarring that occurs in individuals who suffer from severe, 
persistent infections in childhood. Trachomatous scarring is recognized by the presence of easily 
visible white bands on the underside of the upper eyelid. Severe scarring can result in contraction 
of the tarsal conjunctiva which causes the lid margin to roll inwards. This results in buckling of 108 
Sold by @itachibot the lid so the lashes rub on the eye known as trachomatous trichiasis. These lashes can lead to 
corneal opacities and scarring and eventually blindness. The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows: • Stage 1: Incipient - Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious. • Stage 2: Established - Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring. • Stage 3: Cicatrising - Scarring along with active infection. • Stage 4: Healed - Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet. The image below shows trachomatous trichiasis with severe scarring-

questions.question: Question 17: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.explanation:
Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adult 
dose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children. Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used in 
trachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in a 
large-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide application 
of azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy.

questions.question: Question 18: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely 
diagnosis in this 21-year-old man presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia. Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually 
bilateral. The most common site is temporal. 109 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: 93 
Sold by @itachibot A 10 year old malnourished boy is brought with a 2-month history of diminished night vision. 
His dietary history revealed a restricted diet, consisting of mainly chips and nuggets, and he 
would refuse to eat green leafy vegetables. What is the conjunctival change seen in this 
deficiency?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario indicates that this patient has nyctalopia (diminished night vision) 
most likely due to vitamin A deficiency, suggested by his poor consumption of 
vegetables. Changes seen in the conjunctiva in vitamin A deficiency is hyperkeratosis of the 
squamous epithelium. This occurs due to the metaplasia of the non-keratinized epithelium to keratinized epithelium.

questions.question: Question 20: Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to irritation due to caterpillar hair. It is often mistaken for tuberculosis. On examination, small, semitranslucent, reddish and 
yellowish-grey nodules are formed in the conjunctiva, cornea, and iris. Microscopy contains 
caterpillar hair surrounded by giant cells and lymphocytes. Treatment includes excision of the 
nodules in the conjunctiva. The image below shows a patient's eye infected with ophthalmia nodosa.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 28-year-old woman with redness and photophobia of the left eye was seen in the OPD. An 
image of a characteristic lesion of her eye is as shown below. Identify the lesion.
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbar 
conjunctiva near the limbus with associated symptoms of redness and photophobia most likely 
has phlyctenular conjunctivitis. The given finding is referred to as a phlycten. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like 
Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 110 
Sold by @itachibot It is characterized by the following: • Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers • Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer • Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving a 
band-shaped opacity Treatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved. Note: This can be differentiated from pinguecula by the following points: Pinguecula is a yellow triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually remains free 
from conjunctival congestion. The following image shows a yellow patch with tortuous blood 
vessels. There is no congestion as seen with a phlycten.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following should not be considered in the differential of a patient who presents 
with the following finding?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows symblepharon, which is not seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis. It is a 
partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of 
the eyeball. Causes of symblepharon: • Chemical injuries (especially alkalis) • Burns • Ocular cicatrical pemphigoid (OCP) • Steven–Johnson syndrome • Erythema multiforme • Pemphigus bullosa • Membranous conjunctivitis 111 
Sold by @itachibot Management: • Lubrication • Sweeping of fornices • Symblepharon ring • Symblepharon release and amniotic membrane graft

questions.question: Question 23: What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?
questions.explanation:
Chlamydia is at present the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatarum in developed 
countries. Ophthalmia neonatarum also called neonatal conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva 
occurring in an infant <30 days after birth.It should be ruled out in any infant having discharge 
or watering within the first week of birth. Causes include: • Chlamydia(Option A): neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present the 
most common cause in developed countries. • Gonorrhoea(Option B): effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequent 
decline has almost eliminated it's incidence in developed countries. • Staphylococcus aureus(Option D), Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, and 
Streptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatarum • Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatrum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2 
virus from the mother. • Chemical conjunctivitis(Option C) is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics or 
silver nitrate at the time of birth. Causative agent Time of presentatio

questions.question:
Question 24: An 8-year-old boy had to miss school because the matting of his eyelids made it difficult to 
open them in the morning and caused severe pain. His agonized mother rushed him to the 
hospital and reported that he had a fever and red eye for 4 days. Which group of lymph nodes 
is likely to be enlarged?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of fever and red eyes, associated with matting of eyelids and pain, is 
suggestive of conjunctivitis. Lymph from the conjunctiva drains directly into the submandibular 
and preauricular nodes and hence, these group of lymph nodes are likely to be enlarged. The lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva is as follows- • From the medial side, one-third of the superior and medial two-thirds of the inferior conjunctiva 
 Submandibular nodes • From the lateral side, two-thirds of the superior conjunctiva and lateral one-third of the inferior 
conjunctiva  Preauricular nodes Specialized collections of T and B lymphocytes underlying a modified epithelium is known as 
conjunctiva-associated lymphoid tissue (CALT) present in the stroma (substantia propria). It is 
critical in the initiation and regulation of ocular-surface immune responses. Note: The stroma also consists of the accessory lacrimal glands of Krause and Wolfring which 
are exocrine glands responsible for the basal secretion of the middle aqueous layer of the tear 
film. The image given below shows the lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva. 113 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 25: The image of the eye of a 32-year-old woman having superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis is 
given below. Which of the following is commonly associated with it?
questions.explanation:
Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis has a definite association with thyroid dysfunction. It affects 
one or both eyes of middle-aged women and about 65% of patients have abnormal thyroid 
function (usually hyperthyroidism). It is a chronic disease of the superior limbus and the superior bulbar and the tarsal conjunctiva. Clinical features: • Papillary hypertrophy of the superior tarsal plate, often having a diffuse velvety appearance. • Hyperemia of a radial band of the superior bulbar conjunctiva that stains with rose bengal. • • Superior filamentary keratitis that develops in about one-third of cases. Management: • Preservative-free lubricants • Topical acetylcysteine 10% to 20%, four times daily to break down filaments • Topical rebamipide

questions.question:
Question 26: Which of the following statements is not characteristic of pterygium? 96 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue.
options.b: Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen.
options.c: Destruction of Bowman's layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea.
options.d: Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur.

questions.explanation:
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the conjunctival connective tissue occurs in pinguecula 
(and not pterygium). In pterygium, there is elastotic degeneration of collagen with fibrovascular proliferation. It is important to distinguish a pterygium from a pinguecula. A pterygium, while histologically 
similar to a pinguecula, is distinguished by fibrovascular tissue that grows onto the cornea. 114 
Sold by @itachibot Pingueculae do not have vascularized tissue and do not cross the limbus.

questions.question:
Question 27: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On 
examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral 
conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen. Vernal conjunctivitis is also called spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis. It primarily 
affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years. It is primarily a type 1 
hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. Classical features of the conjunctiva in VKC: Palpebral VKC - Cobblestone papillae are present in the upper tarsal conjunctiva associated with 
ropy discharge. Maxwell–Lyon sign is present which is a pseudomembrane formation of the upper 
lid when everted and exposed to heat Limbal VKC - Horner – Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris 
in the limbal area. The image given below shows Horner-Trantas spots. Treatment of this condition is with topical steroids and mast cell stabilizers such as cromolyn 
sodium. Topical cyclosporine can be used in patients who do not respond to first line treatment 
modalities.

questions.question:
Question 28: Your professor has assigned you to proofread a seminar on the anatomy of the conjunctiva 
made by a junior. In the explanation of conjunctival follicles, you spot a wrong statement that 
needs revision. What is that statement?

options.a: Conjunctiva of new born does not produce follicles before 2-3 months of age.
options.b: Slit lamp may be necessary to differentiate between follicles and papillae.
options.c: Follicles are a hyperplasia of the normal vascular system.
options.d: Follicles are found in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.

questions.explanation:
Papillae (not follicles) are hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like 
branches of capillaries growing into the epithelium in inflammatory conditions. On the other 
hand, follicles are yellowish-white, round elevations of 1-2 mm diameter. Follicles are a localized 115 
Sold by @itachibot aggregation of lymphocytes present in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva. Image: Conjunctival papillae (hyperplastic epithelium and capillaries) shown in the first image 
followed by conjunctival giant follicles (round yellowish-white elevations) shown in the second 
image.

Question 29: In the grading of trachoma, the follicular stage is defined by the presence of which of the 
following?
questions.explanation:
In the grading of trachoma, follicular stage is defined by the presence of 5 or more follicles in the 
upper tarsal conjunctiva. Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide. It is caused by an obligate 
intracellular bacterium called Chlamydia trachomatis Serotypes A–C. The infection is transmitted 
by direct or indirect transfer of eye and nose discharges of infected people, particularly young 
children who harbour the principal reservoir of infection. 116
